Class ScaledError

java.lang.Object
net.tvburger.jdl.model.training.loss.ScaledError
All Implemented Interfaces:
BatchLossFunction, DimensionLossFunction, LossFunction, SampleLossFunction
@Decorator @Strategy(role=CONCRETE) public class ScaledError extends Object implements DimensionLossFunction, SampleLossFunction, BatchLossFunction
A decorator loss function that applies a fixed scaling factor to the results of another loss function.

ScaledError can operate at multiple levels of loss calculation — dimension, sample, and batch — by delegating to an underlying LossFunction and scaling its results by a constant multiplier.

For example, when wrapping a SquaredError with a scaling factor of 0.5, this class produces the commonly used Mean Squared Error (MSE) formulation: 

 MSE = 0.5 * (predicted - target)^2

    Creates a new ScaledError that decorates the given LossFunction with a scaling factor.

      public ScaledError(float scale, LossFunction lossFunction)
      Creates a new ScaledError that decorates the given LossFunction with a scaling factor.
      Parameters:

      lossFunction - the underlying LossFunction to decorate

  • Method Details

    • calculateBatchLoss

      public float calculateBatchLoss(List<Pair<float[],float[]>> batch, Pair<SampleLossFunction, List<DimensionLossFunction>> lossFunctions)
      Calculates the total loss for a batch of samples.

      Each sample in the batch is represented as a Pair of float arrays, where the left element is the estimated (predicted) values and the right element is the target (expected) values. The provided SampleLossFunction and associated list of DimensionLossFunctions are used to compute the loss for each sample, which is then aggregated into the batch loss.

      Specified by:
      calculateBatchLoss in interface BatchLossFunction
      Parameters:
      batch - a list of samples, where each sample is a pair of float[] arrays (estimated vs target)
      lossFunctions - a pair consisting of a SampleLossFunction (for per-sample loss calculation) and the list of DimensionLossFunctions used within that sample loss calculation
      Returns:
      the aggregated batch loss as a float

    • calculateDimensionLoss

      public float calculateDimensionLoss(float estimated, float target)
      Calculates the loss for a single dimension, given the estimated value and the target value.
      Specified by:
      calculateDimensionLoss in interface DimensionLossFunction
      Parameters:
      estimated - the predicted or estimated value
      target - the expected or target value
      Returns:
      the loss for this dimension as a float

    • determineGradient

      public float determineGradient(float estimated, float target)
      Determines the gradient of the loss function with respect to the estimated value, for a single dimension.

    • calculateSampleLoss

      public float calculateSampleLoss(Pair<float[],float[]> sample, List<DimensionLossFunction> lossFunctions)
      Calculates the total loss for a sample by applying the corresponding DimensionLossFunction to each element of the estimated and target arrays.
      Specified by:
      calculateSampleLoss in interface SampleLossFunction
      Parameters:
      sample - a pair containing the estimated values (left) and target values (right) for a single sample
      lossFunctions - the list of dimension-specific loss functions to be applied
      Returns:
      the total loss for the sample as a float

    • determineGradients

      public float[] determineGradients(float[] estimated, float[] target, List<DimensionLossFunction> lossFunctions)
      Determines the gradient of the loss function for each dimension of the sample, given the estimated and target arrays.
      Specified by:
      determineGradients in interface SampleLossFunction
      Parameters:
      estimated - the predicted values for the sample
      target - the expected target values for the sample
      lossFunctions - the list of dimension-specific loss functions to be applied
      Returns:
      an array of gradient values, one per dimension
